content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>  <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3 http://www.loc.gov/standards/mods/v3/mods-3-4.xsd">    <titleInfo>       <title>Purity of the stratification by Newton polygons and Frobenius-periodic vector bundles</title>    </titleInfo>    <name type="personal" ID="yy2244">       <namePart type="family">Yang</namePart>       <namePart type="given">Yanhong</namePart>       <role>          <roleTerm type="text">author</roleTerm>       </role>       <affiliation>Columbia University. Mathematics</affiliation>    </name>    <name type="personal" ID="jd2349">       <namePart type="family">de Jong</namePart>       <namePart type="given">Aise Johan</namePart>       <role>          <roleTerm type="text">thesis advisor</roleTerm>       </role>       <affiliation>Columbia University. Mathematics</affiliation>    </name>    <name type="corporate">       <namePart>Columbia University. Mathematics</namePart>       <role>          <roleTerm type="text">originator</roleTerm>       </role>    </name>    <typeOfResource>text</typeOfResource>    <genre>Dissertations</genre>    <originInfo>       <dateIssued keyDate="yes">2013</dateIssued>    </originInfo>    <language>       <languageTerm type="text">English</languageTerm>    </language>    <abstract>This thesis includes two parts. In the first part, we show a purity theorem for stratifications by Newton polygons coming from crystalline cohomology, which says that the family of Newton polygons over a noetherian scheme have a common break point if this is true outside a subscheme of codimension bigger than 1. The proof is similar to the proof of [dJO99, Theorem 4.1]. In the second part, we prove that for every ordinary genus-2 curve X over a finite field k of characteristic 2 with automorphism group Z/2Z \ufffd S_3, there exist SL(2,k[[s]])-representations of π_1(X) such that the image of π_1(X^-) is infinite. This result produces a family of examples similar to Laszlo's counterexample [Las01] to a question regarding the finiteness of the geometric monodromy of representations of the fundamental group [dJ01].</abstract>    <note>Ph.D., Columbia University.</note>    <subject>       <topic>Mathematics</topic>    </subject>    <identifier type="hdl">http://hdl.handle.net/10022/AC:P:20334</identifier>    <location>       <physicalLocation authority="marcorg">NNC</physicalLocation>    </location>    <recordInfo>       <recordContentSource authority="marcorg">NNC</recordContentSource>       <recordCreationDate>2013-05-15 10:21:52 -0400</recordCreationDate>       <recordChangeDate>2013-05-15 10:26:14 -0400</recordChangeDate>       <recordIdentifier>11127</recordIdentifier>       <languageOfCataloging>          <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b">eng</languageTerm>       </languageOfCataloging>    </recordInfo> </mods>
